question.title: how many instances for a class exists at runtime in java

node.contents: You were wrong. You can't do it with reflection.

astNode.text: You were wrong. You can't do it with reflection.

node.contents: Are you allowed to modify the class itself?

astNode.text: Are you allowed to modify the class itself?

node.contents: Today in my interview , i was asked to write a code to determine how many instances for a class exits at runtime in java.

astNode.text: Today in my interview , i was asked to write a code to determine how many instances for a class exits at runtime in java.

node.contents: I told them , that we can use reflection . kindly let me know if you have efficient way of doing this.

astNode.text: I told them , that we can use reflection . kindly let me know if you have efficient way of doing this.

node.contents: and with synchronization expected

astNode.text: and with synchronization expected

node.contents: @Gopi, I left that out for simplicity. mdma shows one way to do it.

astNode.text: @Gopi, I left that out for simplicity. mdma shows one way to do it.

node.contents: I don't think you can do it for an arbitrary class with reflection. Probably he just expected you to add a static counter field:

astNode.text: I don't think you can do it for an arbitrary class with reflection. Probably he just expected you to add a static counter field:

elements.contents: public class Foo { private static int counter = 0; public Foo() { counter++; } }

units.rawText: public class Foo { private static int counter = 0; public Foo() { counter++; } }

node.contents: Or you could make the class a singleton, then you could just "return singletonObject == null ? 0 : 1;"

astNode.text: Or you could make the class a singleton, then you could just "return singletonObject == null ? 0 : 1;"

node.contents: Mr. Badguy could challenge this by means of reflection.

astNode.text: Mr. Badguy could challenge this by means of reflection.

node.contents: If you restrict instance generation by providing an accessor method and a provate constructor (like in a Singleton pattern) then you can keep count on how many times you create a new instance.

astNode.text: If you restrict instance generation by providing an accessor method and a provate constructor (like in a Singleton pattern) then you can keep count on how many times you create a new instance.

node.contents: a small thought , is it possible to know count for instances if other class creates

node.contents: All instantiations of the class are tracked, no matter who creates the class.

astNode.text: All instantiations of the class are tracked, no matter who creates the class.

node.contents: The Unsafe class is not part of the official JDK api. I could have a custom VM that does object pooling on value objects rather than allocating new instances. If we start talking mechanisms outside the JDK that mess with instantiation then of course we cannot track all instances.

astNode.text: The Unsafe class is not part of the official JDK api. I could have a custom VM that does object pooling on value objects rather than allocating new instances. If we start talking mechanisms outside the JDK that mess with instantiation then of course we cannot track all instances.

node.contents: This still cannot track all instantiations because an object may be created with [`Unsafe.allocateInstance`](http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/sun/misc/Unsafe.java#Unsafe.allocateInstance%28java.lang.Class%29)

astNode.text: This still cannot track all instantiations because an object may be created with [`Unsafe.allocateInstance`](http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/root/jdk/openjdk/6-b14/sun/misc/Unsafe.java#Unsafe.allocateInstance%28java.lang.Class%29)

node.contents: I don't think reflection will help you. There is the JVMTI (and the older and now defunct JVMPI) which can be used to analyse the heap and determine the number of current instances of a class.

astNode.text: I don't think reflection will help you. There is the JVMTI (and the older and now defunct JVMPI) which can be used to analyse the heap and determine the number of current instances of a class.

node.contents: A coded alternative is to add a counter to the class you want to track instances of:

astNode.text: A coded alternative is to add a counter to the class you want to track instances of:

elements.contents: class Myclass { static private final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(); { count.getAndIncrement(); } static public int instanceCount() { return count.get(); } // edit: account for serializable private void readObject(ObjectInputStream ois) throws ClassNotFoundException, IOException { counter.getAndIncrement(); ois.defaultReadObject(); } }

comments.text: // edit: account for serializable private void readObject(ObjectInputStream ois) throws ClassNotFoundException, IOException { counter.getAndIncrement(); ois.defaultReadObject(); } }

node.contents: This will track the number of instances ever created, and is thread-safe. To find out when instances are garbage collected, you can use a PhantomReference and a ReferenceQueue to track collected instances and decrement the counter.

astNode.text: This will track the number of instances ever created, and is thread-safe. To find out when instances are garbage collected, you can use a PhantomReference and a ReferenceQueue to track collected instances and decrement the counter.

elements.contents: class Myclass { static private final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(); static private final ReferenceQueue<MyClass> queue = new ReferenceQueue<MyClass>(); { count.getAndIncrement(); new PhantomReference<MyObject>(this, queue); } static public int instanceCount() { return count.get(); } static { Thread t = new Thread() { public void run() { for (;;) { queue.remove(); count.decrementAndGet(); } } }; t.setDaemon(true); t.start(); } }

units.rawText: class Myclass { static private final AtomicInteger count = new AtomicInteger(); static private final ReferenceQueue<MyClass> queue = new ReferenceQueue<MyClass>(); { count.getAndIncrement(); new PhantomReference<MyObject>(this, queue); } static public int instanceCount() { return count.get(); } static { Thread t = new Thread() { public void run() { for (;;) { queue.remove(); count.decrementAndGet(); } } }; t.setDaemon(true); t.start(); } }

node.contents: EDIT:

astNode.text: EDIT:

node.contents: If the class is serializeable, implement the readObject method and increment the counter. I've added this to the first code example.
